title: Percy FitzGerald
text:
<a href="Brigadier%20General">Brigadier General</a> Percy Desmond FitzGerald, (18 April 1873 – 17 August 1933) was a <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> officer in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> and a sportsman, playing <a href="polo">polo</a> and <a href="cricket">cricket</a> at competition levels.
Born in Australia, he moved to Great Britain and joined the army, initially serving in the <a href="Buffs%20%28Royal%20East%20Kent%20Regiment%29">Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment)</a>, and then the <a href="11th%20%28Prince%20Albert%27s%20Own%29%20Hussars">11th (Prince Albert's Own) Hussars</a>. The highlight of his military career was as commander of the <a href="5th%20Mounted%20Brigade">5th Mounted Brigade</a> during the <a href="Sinai%20and%20Palestine%20campaign">Sinai and Palestine campaign</a>.
Civilian life.
Percy Desmond FitzGerald was born 18 April 1873 in <a href="St%20Kilda%2C%20Victoria">St Kilda</a>, <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>. He was the son of <a href="Nicholas%20Fitzgerald%20%28politician%29">Nicholas FitzGerald</a> and Marianne (née O'Shanassy). His father was member of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Victoria">Parliament of Victoria</a>, having moved there in 1859 and established the <a href="Castlemaine%20Perkins">Castlemaine brewery</a>.
FitzGerald was educated at <a href="St%20Mary%27s%20College%2C%20Oscott">St Mary's College, Oscott</a>. He became a <a href="First-class%20cricket">first-class</a> <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er with the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> in 1897, and a <a href="polo">polo</a> player competing several times for the <a href="Roehampton%20Trophy">Roehampton Trophy</a>.
In October 1914, during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, he married <a href="Millicent%20Leveson-Gower%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Sutherland">Lady Millicent Fanny St. Clair-Erskine</a>, the daughter of <a href="Robert%20St%20Clair-Erskine%2C%204th%20Earl%20of%20Rosslyn">Robert St Clair-Erskine, 4th Earl of Rosslyn</a> and Blanche Adeliza Fitzroy. The marriage was annulled without issue in 1919. FitzGerald died in <a href="Marylebone">Marylebone</a>, London, on 17 August 1933.
Military career.
FitzGerald's military career began with the <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victorian</a> local military force, but in December 1893 he became a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Buffs%20%28Royal%20East%20Kent%20Regiment%29">Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment)</a>. While still a second lieutenant he transferred from the Buffs to the <a href="11th%20%28Prince%20Albert%27s%20Own%29%20Hussars">11th (Prince Albert's Own) Hussars</a> in January 1894, and on 20 November 1897 he was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a>.
FitzGerald saw service in the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a>, being <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">mentioned in despatches</a> four times and awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> in 1901. His <a href="Queen%27s%20South%20Africa%20Medal">Queen's South Africa Medal</a> had four clasps: <a href="Battle%20of%20Bergendal">Belfast</a>, <a href="Orange%20Free%20State">Orange Free State</a>, <a href="Siege%20of%20Ladysmith">Defence of Ladysmith</a>, <a href="Laing%27s%20Nek">Laing's Nek</a>. While still in South Africa, he was appointed <a href="adjutant">adjutant</a> of his regiment on 6 May 1902. Following the war, in December 1903, FitGerald became the <a href="Aide-de-Camp">Aide-de-Camp</a> to Brigadier General <a href="Michael%20Rimington">Michael Rimington</a>, commanding the <a href="3rd%20Cavalry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">3rd Cavalry Brigade</a>. Then, in January 1905, he was promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a>. By 1913, FitzGerald had been promoted to <a href="major">major</a> and was holding the position of a <a href="Brigade%20Major">Brigade Major</a>, <a href="Staff%20Officer">Staff Officer</a> at the <a href="War%20Office">War Office</a>.
At the start of the First World War he was <a href="General%20Staff%20Officer">General Staff Officer</a> Grade 2. He eventually became a <a href="brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> and temporary <a href="brigadier%20general">brigadier general</a>, commanding the <a href="5th%20Mounted%20Brigade">5th Mounted Brigade</a> in the <a href="Sinai%20and%20Palestine%20campaign">Sinai and Palestine campaign</a>. During the war he was again mentioned in despatches, and awarded the French <a href="Legion%20of%20Honour">Legion of Honour</a>. He retired from the army in 1920.
